question_text: What are the fundamental physical mechanisms behind supercooling in PCMs, and how does the critical radius of solid nuclei R_cr influence the degree of supercooling according to the mathematical relationship T_sc = (4/3)(γ_o T_m)/(ρ_s H_s-l R_cr)?
standard_answer: Supercooling occurs due to nucleation barriers where PCMs remain liquid below their equilibrium freezing temperature. The physical mechanisms involve: (1) Surface energy effects where the interface energy γ_o between solid nuclei and liquid creates an energy barrier that must be overcome for nucleation; (2) The critical radius R_cr represents the minimum stable nucleus size, below which surface tension forces dominate and cause dissolution; (3) The enthalpy of fusion H_s-l provides the driving force for phase transition, with larger values requiring more significant undercooling to initiate nucleation; (4) Density differences between solid and liquid phases affect the volumetric work required for nucleus formation. The mathematical relationship shows that supercooling degree T_sc increases with higher surface energy γ_o and melting temperature T_m, but decreases with larger R_cr, higher solid density ρ_s, and greater latent heat H_s-l. Smaller capsule sizes in micro/nano-encapsulation reduce the probability of containing nucleation sites, thereby increasing supercooling as each capsule has insufficient impurities to initiate heterogeneous nucleation.

original_text.1: It is also possible to express supercooling as follows: T_sc = (4/3)(γ_o T_m)/(ρ_s H_s-l R_cr)
original_text.2: The degree of supercooling is definitely increased if the bulk volume is divided into microscopic particles through encapsulation or an emulsion process, because each capsule will have an insufficient number of impurities
